repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body:
### Problem:
Currently, if prompt gets changed during user-input with prompt_setprompt() it only gets reflected in next prompt. And that behavrior is not also consistent. If user re-enters insert mode then the user input gets discarded and a new prompt gets created with the new pormpt.

### Solution:
Respond to prompt_setprompt right away. Change the prompt and keep user input.

fix #37744

comment_data.body: just curious, which change effected this? related to https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/14116 ?

to avoid analyzer warnings, should we assert after these casts?

```
assert(old_prompt_len > 0);
...
```
The static analyzer warnings went away after adding null check. Which warnings are you seeing?
They are different. This basically make it so when we insert-prompt the buffer doesn't get marked as modified. But on user-input it still becomes modified.
comparing OK explicitly is a good practice, it's not a boolean.
Ok will add explicit check. But the ok isn't the issue here. The function is returning ok and still leaking the memory. Which is very odd.

does `new_prompt` need to be freed? though if so, need to think about `xstrdup(new_prompt)` below.

it may be clearer to avoid these if/else branches and deal with one `new_prompt`

That wasn't the issue. I think the issue was I was setting buffer-lines before some initialization was already done, probably that was causing some dangling state. When I was running the tests with asan on my machine I couldn't reproduce it. So it's hard to pin point what exactly causing the leak. But if we make sure the buffer is a prompt buffer that dangling state no longer happens. And fixes the leak while keeping the feature intact. And I've set the mark-colum to update with change in prompt. That should fix the breaking issues we were getting in different plugins (telescope, NeoTree, Nui,.... etc)

comment_regular_data.body: Thank you. I can't comment on this change in general, but at least it solves the reported problem. ~Finally after some modification of https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/36194#issuecomment-3857961906 I found a working repro so I can create an issue.~

```lua
local function init()
  local api = vim.api
  local buf = api.nvim_create_buf(false, true)
  api.nvim_open_win(buf, true, {height = 1, width = 40, relative = 'editor', col = 0, row = 0})

  local prompt = '> '
  vim.bo[buf].buftype = 'prompt'
  vim.fn.prompt_setprompt(buf, prompt)
  api.nvim_buf_set_lines(buf, 0, -1, false, {prompt .. 'query'})
  api.nvim_feedkeys('A', 'n', false)
end

-- schedule because of https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/12295
-- considered as not a bug
vim.schedule(init)
```

I noticed that both here and in https://github.com/nvim-telescope/telescope.nvim/issues/3617 the prompt text is not cleared, but the buffer gets the second line. It is easy to see it in the minimal repro after switching to Normal mode. In Telescope we need to call `:lua vim.api.nvim_win_set_cursor(0, {1, 1})`.
Do we need a test change to exercise this scenario?

> Do we need a test change to exercise this scenario?

Yeah ofcourse. I'll add tests. Forgot about it

> I noticed that both here and in https://github.com/nvim-telescope/telescope.nvim/issues/3617 the prompt text is not cleared, but the buffer gets the second line. It is easy to see it in the minimal repro after switching to Normal mode. In Telescope we need to call :lua vim.api.nvim_win_set_cursor(0, {1, 1}).

Yeah it's creating a new line due to prompt mis-match. on telescope end you can work around the quark (alongside curson you'll also need to set the `:` marks position too). I'd just prefer the quark not to be there.


title: feat(prompt): allow prompt to be changed without disrupting user input
